node.statement: (Vitali convergence under the tilted measure and identification of the limit) On the Skorokhod coupling space (Omega, F, P) from node 1.6.3.2, with Y_eps = exp(Psi_eps^{ren}(Phi_eps)), W_eps = exp(L_eps(Phi_eps)), Y = exp(Psi^{ren}(Phi)), and Z = E_P[Y]. CLAIM: For all bounded continuous G on C^{-1/2-delta}(T^3): E_P[G(Phi_eps) Y_eps W_eps] / E_P[Y_eps W_eps] -> (1/Z) E_P[G(Phi) Y] = E_rho[G]. PROOF: Step 1 (Reformulate as expectations under the tilted measure). Define the probability measure Q_eps on (Omega, F) by dQ_eps/dP = W_eps / E_P[W_eps] (well-defined since W_eps = exp(L_eps(Phi_eps)) > 0 and E_P[W_eps] = E_{mu_eps}[exp(L_eps)] is finite by node 1.5.4). Then: E_P[G Y_eps W_eps] / E_P[Y_eps W_eps] = E_{Q_eps}[G(Phi_eps) Y_eps] / E_{Q_eps}[Y_eps]. Now, the law of Phi_eps under Q_eps is mu_eps^L (the L_eps-tilted measure from node 1.6.4.3), because for any bounded measurable H: E_{Q_eps}[H(Phi_eps)] = E_P[H(Phi_eps) W_eps] / E_P[W_eps] = E_{mu_eps}[H exp(L_eps)] / E_{mu_eps}[exp(L_eps)] = E_{mu_eps^L}[H]. Step 2 (Skorokhod coupling for the tilted measures). By node 1.6.4.3, mu_eps^L -> mu weakly on C^{-1/2-delta}(T^3). Since C^{-1/2-delta}(T^3) is a Polish space, by the Skorokhod representation theorem, there exist a probability space (Omega2, F2, P2) and random variables Xi_eps, Xi valued in the enhanced data space X with law(Xi_eps) = mu_eps^L under P2, law(Xi) = mu under P2, and Xi_eps -> Xi P2-a.s. Step 3 (Transfer Y_eps to the new coupling). Define Y_eps2 := exp(Psi_eps^{ren}(Xi_eps)) and Y2 := exp(Psi^{ren}(Xi)). By the SAME arguments as nodes 1.6.3.2 and 1.6.3.4 (a.s. convergence of Psi_eps^{ren} and uniform integrability of exp(Psi_eps^{ren})), applied to the new Skorokhod coupling: (a) Psi_eps^{ren}(Xi_eps) -> Psi^{ren}(Xi) P2-a.s. (by continuity of the Besov duality pairings, exactly as in 1.6.3.2). (b) {exp(Psi_eps^{ren}(Xi_eps))} is uniformly integrable on (Omega2, P2). This holds because: E_{P2}[exp((1+delta) Psi_eps^{ren}(Xi_eps))] = E_{mu_eps^L}[exp((1+delta) Psi_eps^{ren})]. Now, by node 1.6.4.3 Step 2, mu_eps^L = (Z_eps^L)^{-1} exp(-V_eps^L) dmu_0 where V_eps^L has the same quartic part as V_eps. The uniform exponential bounds on E_{mu_eps}[exp(alpha <f, :phi^k:>)] (node 1.6.2.10.2.4) hold for mu_eps^L as well, because the Boue-Dupuis variational estimates and Young inequality arguments (which give the quartic domination bound) depend only on the quartic coupling lambda and the covariance structure C_eps, not on the precise form of the quadratic term. Therefore sup_eps E_{mu_eps^L}[exp((1+delta) |Psi_eps^{ren}|)] < infinity, giving UI by the Vitali criterion. CONSEQUENCE: By the Vitali convergence theorem on (Omega2, P2): E_{P2}[G(Xi_eps) exp(Psi_eps^{ren}(Xi_eps))] -> E_{P2}[G(Xi) exp(Psi^{ren}(Xi))] = E_mu[G exp(Psi^{ren})]. And E_{P2}[exp(Psi_eps^{ren}(Xi_eps))] -> E_{P2}[exp(Psi^{ren}(Xi))] = E_mu[exp(Psi^{ren})] = Z. Step 4 (Conclude). E_{Q_eps}[G(Phi_eps) Y_eps] / E_{Q_eps}[Y_eps] = E_{mu_eps^L}[G exp(Psi_eps^{ren})] / E_{mu_eps^L}[exp(Psi_eps^{ren})] = E_{P2}[G(Xi_eps) Y_eps2] / E_{P2}[Y_eps2] -> E_mu[G exp(Psi^{ren})] / Z = E_rho[G]. Therefore E_P[G(Phi_eps) Y_eps W_eps] / E_P[Y_eps W_eps] -> E_rho[G]. DEPENDENCIES: 1.6.3.2, 1.6.3.4, 1.6.4.2, 1.6.4.3, 1.6.2.10.2.4.
